transcript.content: Yeah yeah yeah – Darkness. I Believe in a Thing Called Love, on Xfm 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais, You’re..
Steve Merchant, are you sure? That’s little Karl Pilkington over there. Where is he?
Think it went well last week, didn’t it, Karl? Good show, wasn’t it?
You loved it, didn’t you, Karl?
Yeah? Now, uh, you weren’t speaking to Suzanne last week at this time.

Because, she had her hair cut, probably quite an expensive haircut, she’s a lady in media, she’s got to look good, so she goes, probably doesn’t go to the barber like you, or just shave it, at home, probably spent quite a little bit of money on it. She came home, she thought, my, my – my sweetheart-
My lover, my sweetheart, you know what I mean? The man in my life, is gonna love this –
Well he adores everything about me, he’s gonna love my hair.
She walked in – ‘Hello Karl’ ‘All right? You look like Dave Hill from Slade’
Is what you said to the poor woman. And THEN! Talked about it on air, she was furious about that. So what did you do?
She did listen, yeah. And she wasn’t happy.
She heard you were slagging her hair off.
Yeah. Well... well what annoys me...
This is probably annoying her now.
No, no, it doesn’t matter, we can do a lot today because she’s at work.
And of course no one’s gonna tell her!
Let’s have a chat about her fat arse!
You are in so much trouble!
Look – he’s realised . He has... he is a little bit worried! Oh! Didn’t – didn’t you go and buy her a coat or summat?
Took her, took her out on Sunday, treated her to a new coat and that...
I offered as well, I said, I said I’d pay to her to have it done again.
So she listened to the show, what did she say? You got home – she’d heard you slaggin’ her hair off.
I mean, imagine, imagine that – he thinks that’s a good thing. Sorta like ‘We'vw won the pools!’ ‘Brilliant! What we doing?’ ‘Well you can have facial surgery now, love!’
It’s sorta like … it’s just … Christ! You offered to have it done again. Unbelievable.
(Stammers) I got home and, uh, she’s like all, bit moody with me. All right?
You thought, ‘Summat’s wrong, she must’ve listened to the show, when I waas slaggin’ off her hair’.
Well his first thought probably was ‘She’s probably looked at herself in the mirror. She agrees with me’.
Yup. The barber’s been round again! Yeah?

And um, she just said, ‘Aw, that wasn’t very nice of you, was it?’ So I just said ‘Hang on a minute.’ I said, ‘That’s, that’s what we do on the show. When I’m slaggin’ off, you know, Chinese people lookin’ old or whatever,’ I said ‘You never interfere’.
She’s got to get her priorities straight.
I love the fact that she’s in the same queue as a billion people you’ve never met.
That’s fantastic. She’s in the same queue. 'Well … you didn’t complain, love...'
‘Cause Karl, I don’t think Karl has ever admitted he might be in the wrong, ever. Certainly not to you or I.
He’s never admitted that he might be in the wrong. So did you, in this instance, agree that maybe you’d overstepped the mark?
No – I just said she, she took it badly.
Do you know what I mean? I mean it’s only a haircut.
See – you haven’t seen it. So, you can’t, you can’t start interfering.
I haven’t seen it. But I, I very much doubt she looks like Dave Hill from Slade. Who, unless I’m mistaken, used to cut his hair with garden sheers blindfolded.
Um, so – you know what I mean? And did her teeth stick out and did she start speakin’ with a Brummie accent as well?
Got used to it now anyway.
So you bought – so at one point, at some point you came crawling back and said, ‘Do you want me to buy you a coat?’
I just said ‘Let’s, let’s leave that. Let’s go out, and have a good weekend. Get your hat before we go.'
Treated her to a new coat and that.
It’s a nice coat, so it takes, people will look at that rather than...
What’s it do? Flash? It’s got obscenities across the back?
If anyone who knows Karl’s girlfriend is listening...
And uh, maybe you’re a work colleague and you’re listening to the show.
Cos I think this is terrible.
Get her to phone him NOW.
Get her to phone him now, I mean, forget the hair.
What, what’s the fat arse complaint line? Because you are in deep shite.
Cemetery Gates, by The Smiths. Of course, off The Queen is Dead, album. Lovely tune. Makes you happy, doesn’t it?
It’s a nice song about dead people.
Yeah. Beautiful. I uh, just wondering, Rick, what your opinions, what your thoughts are on, Britney Spears.
Uh – liked a couple. Bit bored. She’s - I think she’s panicking a little bit, I think she’s a bit desperate with all this Madonna stuff...
Yeah, all the kind of lesbian...
Yeah, I dunno, I dunno. Um, dunno – yeah, she’s all right. I’ve got nothing against the girl.
Well I read, I think it was in Hot Tickets magazine, free with the Evening Standard … um, ooh – I might get some free Evening Standards now! I’ve plugged that!
I um, was just reading in there, that, I don’t know if this is still gonna happen but apparently she was gonna do a, uh, a little cheeky appearance at G.A.Y.
In, um, in London. And uh, obviously, I was quite excited, ‘cause I’m a Spears fan –
D’ya – Sorry, you know what that spells, don’t ya?
Yeah yeah yeah. Well I think it is a gay club.
This is what – this is what I was ascertaining from the article.
Ohhh... so... that’s what they’ve said … they’ve called it, what, sort of what it is.

And um, and perhaps she was gonna be, um, be previewing some of her new album live on stage, at G.A.Y. Now that’s an intimate venue, normally you get to see someone like Spears probably Wembley Arena, somewhere -
I’m thinkin’, ‘I’m a Spears fan. Get a couple of the gang together’

Cruise down there. But um, but then I read on in the article that apparently, the doormen at G.A.Y., were only gonna let in – uhhh – regulars. And the way they were gonna ascertain if you were a regular was by asking a series of questions at the door.
What – testing if you were really –
Testing – now, I don’t know if the questions would be about the interior of G.A.Y.
Or the interior of, someone else, yeah.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Or, or just general, kind of –
What – well, do you reckon you woulda passed the, uh, the test?
Well that’s what I was wondering –
So, so you’d have had to pretend to be –
G.A.Y, to get in, to see Spears. Now that –
Can you say ‘gay’ on the radio?
Yep. I think so. Um, but, it’s irony, isn’t it. So you’re pretending to be gay to get into a club to see, a bird you like?
I’ll – I’ll give you a little quick test.
Shall I? Um, all right. Uh – all right – what’s, sorry, what’s your name? Mate?

Um, right, you haven’t done a lot with your hair – you just sorta let it, sorta let it grow out, I mean, would you be puttin’ product on a bit later, ‘cause I mean, you don’t look, very, I mean, sort of like, you look sort of quite...
Yeah, well, sorta like, like you didn’t care, like you have no care about how you look, like you’re a –
Yeah well normally it would be shaved.
Ahh, OK. You say normally, now that would, that looks like about, like 3 months growth there. Why would you...
No, that’s why, I’ve let it, grow. So it’s, grown...
OK! So what, what time would you normally be goin’ out then?
Normally I’d go out about, sort of, uh, I’d go out about 8ish.
8 — 8:00 in the evening, you’d go out!
‘Cause that sounds, sounds a bit early. That’s what - nor–
No, I’d go out about, 3 in the morning, normally.
Right. So I (mutters)... so that’s right, that’s right, yeah. Where’d you go, sort of, Old Compton Street for a coffee and then, on to, G.A.Y.
With your little shaved – head. UM, OK, well, d’- d’ – you’re doin’ fine, you sounded great –
Can I just ask you one final question?
I’ll give you 20 bender points, I’m just gonna let you in, I’m just gonna tell the guards to let you in, BUT, there’s just one more question: Do you prefer... knobs or tits, Paulo?
Knobs. You like knobs, do ya? Can’t get enough, knobs, so you, what, you hate tits, I assume?
I don’t know what to say! I – yeah … I love hers.
But not in a, straight way.
Not in a straight way, in a gay way.
So, OK. OK. So you love knobs more than tits, right. OK, OK. In ya go!
You know Britney’s on, do ya?
See? That’s what would give me away...
Well, you, (stammers) I think you’re probably a bit 'bi'.
Yeah. But I mean, go in anyway.
OK, drinks are quite expensive. Pop your shirt off, will ya.
Hey-ya. Outkast. On Xfm 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington. You all right, Karl?
Yeah yeah yeah, not bad. Just um … when you were talkin’ just now, about, about the gay stuff, right, I don’t know if you saw, uh, thing in the week, about the fella, who’s on that, quiz show.
Gay fella … straight, sort of man. Man-woman.
What you talkin’ about? What? Tell me the … r- right- w-what did you see? Tell me what you saw.

This is like a kid come runnin’ in, and he’s seen somethin’ frightening, and it could be an alien, could be a ghost, could be a paedophile, and you’ve got to get exactly what actually he saw out of him. Right, what did you actually see?
Just this, this fella who’s, uh, who’s a woman.
Right! OK! Right, try and talk, like a – human being. Right.
See it’s a quiz show, that’s comin’ on the telly. And um, it’s this, this woman –
Uh! Right! Is it a fella who’s a woman, or is it a woman?
Bit ‘a both, that’s why I’m talkin’ about it.
But what do you mean?! Is it a pre-op...
...a lady boy, is it a hermaphrodite, what is it?
I’m tellin’ you! It’s, it’s, it’s a woman. Well, it’s a man –
OH! For-- forget it! Play a record!
It is a man. He is a man. Well –
It’s a TV program where, they’ve got this –
It is a transvestite, yeah... But, but the problem is – I’ll tell ya, just, ‘cause you don’t know about it, the program is -
I – I still don’t know about it! I don’t know anything about it, still, I don’t know anything – ‘Woman – man – man – woman – man. Man – woman – TV – TV program – TV!’
No, it’s a man who is now sort of half a woman.
A man who’s now half a woman!
No, well this is what’s weird about it! He, he’s got the top half, but not the bottom half sorted out.
What you mean, he – he’s got breasts and a wig, but he’s still got his, his boys, downstairs. He’s –
His captain and the boys, are still there in his Y-fronts...
...but upstairs he’s got a lovely pair of dumplings.
But why not get it done in one, one go?
Well, wait, till you you’ve got all the money! That just looks a mess.
Well he wakes in the morning, pleasin’ himself, he can’t believe his luck! He doesn’t know where to start!
No, but what I don’t understand, I mean, I don’t – I don’t want to seem —
Can I just finish that sentence? What you don’t understand is just about everything.
I find it weird, right, I sort of get – I, I understand the gay thing, right?
Well tell me the gay thing. Explain the gay thing.
Well, I just know if, you’re a fella, you like, you like men. I don’t know, much more than that.
Well what I mean is, with transvestites, what’s going on there? Wh-what do they want?
Transvestite is, is, is a, a cross dresser.
(pause) See – I don’t, I don’t get that either. Because...
Normally, that’s a man, who likes to dress in women’s clothing. It’s not necessarily, they’re not necessarily gay -
They’re not gay, they’re often not gay –
They just happen to like wearing women’s clothes.
But, but, then why not wear women’s clothes, that, could be seen as a bloke’s? Like – Suzanne wears jeans.
No, but they – that’s the thing –

(Stammers) But – but that’s their problem, isn’t it. They, they, they like being seen as a, as a, as a, as a woman. They like being seen as a woman. It’s not just that it’s more comfortable, or they’d wear a kilt. They like being seen as a woman. They feel more comfortable.
(pauses) All right. And what’s the deal with this fella who’s got –
We don’t know who this fella is.
No. We don’t know this man who’s half a woman.

So, all he’s done, he’s, he’s had the tits done, he’s probably had the hormones, probably lived as a woman for awhile, the last step, ‘cause you could probably reverse the breasts anyway, ‘cause they’re, they’re probably implants, and hormonal things, and, whereas, y’ ya’ chop your knob and, um, boys off, that’s, uh, you have that the next day and go, ‘Sorry, I didn’t mean that – I wanted me ears pierced. It’s a bit more of a bigger operation, to put them back. So, doctors are probably making sure that he’s –
Surely you’ve had the top half done, you’re not going to go back on what, you’ve said?
But then, what’s the top half being done? You mean, you, I could – I could have, get you breast implants, give you a bit of hormonal treatment –
Now that would be a great idea for next week’s show.
And, and you could reverse it. What you can’t do is grow a knob back.
Well, you can! Last week was all about growing one on your arm!
So that is possible. But the thing is, the truth of it is, is, I think I do know about this story. I think it was a television program called "There’s Something about Miriam."
The conceit of which was that this pre-op, transsexual –
So I guessed that right. Yeah.
Um, was masquerading as a woman.
And, various blokes, under – who didn’t realize that this was a man – had to, um...
Try to seduce – him/her. And, when they found out that it was actually a bloke, and they, a lot of them had kissed, uh, him/her. They um –
They err, they refused to let it be shown.
I agree though, I I, that's terrible.
But I mean, you know, that's awful, I yeah I, I hated that
I think it was a Sky One programme, is there anything other than The Simpsons on Sky One worth watching?
Have you ever tried to watch that programme, have you ever seen Kirsty's Home Videos?
But it's things like dogs on a slide, babies falling over err.
Do you know it's only recently reduced from an hour in length.
Used to be an hour long, and it's just, if you havn't seen it it's just camcorder footage like 'You've Been Framed'.
I like an old woman at a wedding falling over and showing her bloomers.
But i like it when it's Kirsty's err Home Videos Uncut, so it's kind of 4 old women like naked.
Aww christ, imagine that. Does it whistle?
It's just a it's just I mean, have you ever really sat and watched anything on Sky One.
I think that's what, that's what I watch, I think that's pretty much what I watch.
They have WWF Wrestling, cartoons, and just the worst programmes I mean it's appalling.
I have seen a bit of the wrestling, it's it's hilarious, it is hilarious.
But it's like a, like a station made by, a fourteen year old boy.
Yeah, well I think that, think that's probably what it is isn't it, I mean that, that's exactly the demographic, Do you like Sky One Karl?
Err, I havn't got, havn't got satellite have I so.
Why not why not?, I'd have thought you'd have loved that.
I know I would love it, I'd love a bit of that.
I was reading about slugs the other day.
There's a thing err on one of the channels called Monkey Business.
Cos I was doing that thing wasn't I, with Richard Bacon.
Where you watch the telly and that and...
You actually talk riddles and forget, play a record.
You should be the gatekeeper at some kind of Dungeons and Dragons.
"Alright? yea" "Let me enter" "Alright yeah but I was doing that thing with Richard Bacon". What can he mean? What can he mean, he is the wise  one. Play a record.
There a man who's also a woman.
The upper half is, but is the bottom?
Johnny Cash, Hurt, on Xfm 104.9, that's brilliant isn't it?
I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl, Pilkington. So, what've we done? We've done gays, transvestites, have we done knob news yet or...
It's nice that you can talk about pre-op transsexuals nowadays on the radio.
You know without the fear of complaints or listeners.
Listeners! That's the thing, if we had any listeners we'd get complaints wouldn't we.
We'd get some serious complaints if anyone cared enough.
That's why we havn't gone to a a decent station, with you know a big audience.
We could never do, on a real radio station we could never do this could we.
Why not, why not? See I'm not doing this to mess about and offend anyone, I think it's an interesting topic.
What, you talking gobbledegook, not really knowing what on earth you're on about.
Karl! For the first 5 minutes you couldn't talk.
Although although we've you know, who's the biggest most professional person in radio, it's probably Terry Wogan isn't it.
And isn't it you that said you can't tell what the sentence he's saying because.
He keeps going up at the end before and after.
So he'll just segue from one point to the next and he'll be like 'Going on my holidays Friday we're having a lovely time says Mrs Derbyshire...
Of Westminster, I'm thinking of going to Greece'
So he's got his knobs, but he's still got the tits.
"Do you want to come into my club to see?
"Yeah I love, yeah Britney Spears I'm a massive fan".
"Yeah, well it doesn't start for a while but it's err only about 8 O'Clock and it's you know, you're not going out for hours yet are you? 'Bout 8 or something, but erm".
"Might as well watch a bit of telly, we've got err FA cup final".
"Oh, just err, that's a good one isn't it, or we've got erm the Eurovision Song Contest, what do you want to watch Paulo?"
"Mmm blimy blimy, well I love all the erm camp and lame".
"Of the Eurovision Song Contest but I, aww, is that David Beckham playing? Cos I love him and his hair and his legs".
"So you want to watch the football".
"But you'll be mainly looking at the...".
"The the legs and the tight tight shorts".
Did you noticed I mean I don't, I mean I never really but when you see old clips of say early 80s footballers, the shorts are much tighter aren't they.
I think I mean, I don't know, I don't look, I don't look.
I don't know I wasn't really looking.
Do you, I remember Karl said saying when he went and there was two strippers, and bloke and a woman, and they whipped off their clothes at the same time, and you looked straight at the boys pack...
Yeah, everybody would, you would've done.
You do do? You look at his do do, what do you mean?
You look at his do do, what.
No I was just saying the, if you were there you woulda done the same, two people on the stage.
Woman, and a man, they were getting their clothes off.
Right, the fella, took his pants off the same time as the girl took her knickers off.
Right, all I'm saying is it's human nature, to have a have a quick look, have a quick glance, see what's going on.
See what's going on! What do you mean?
I wanted, and I wanted to look at the woman but she put her knickers back on quick.
She didn't live opposite from you did she?
But just sorry, just to return briefly to the shorts question, I...
Suddenly cos in the 30s and 40s they were huge shorts weren't they.
A small child could wear them as trousers they were so.
I think that had to do with comfort and decency though isn't it.
And then, but by the sort of eighties, there was barely any shorts there.
But it's weird that it's, you feel like at someone point someones gone "Guys, I mean good game today but".
But that's what happened isn't it because you know things get bigger and bigger and bigger, and then they get smaller and smaller and smaller.
And fashion, sort of like Flares, Drainpipes.
What do you make of the miniskirt?

Err, long hair, skinhead. Miniskirt err again I dunno they I, I'm sure there's been 10 resurgences of miniskirts since '65 or whatever it was, you know it's fashion so the short. You know what, d'yer know what I think Steve? I think the shorts'll get smaller again before we die.
I think we'll see one more tight little packet or Premiership footballers running round with their offal squeezed like, like the last chicken in a butcher's window.
Wrapped up, yeah. Imagine if they just wore cling-film shorts so you could just see what was happening in there, Karl? Where would you look then? Cos you like football don't yer?
Ooh we gotta do a bit of Rockbusters.
Right, err we brought it back, this is err, where I give a cryptic clue.
And some initials, and you work it out and you win some stuff.
Yeah, I was gonna tell you what the prizes are, needless to say, they're mediocre prizes for a mediocre quiz.
Sure ok yeah, well there's DVDs and VHS yeah, yeah yeah yeah VHS who's still…
Couple of videos and DVDs and that. Right so there's 3, three of them, and what you can do now, we've tweeked it a bit.
You can text in, right, so you can e-mail or text.
83Xfm is the text, or it's [email protected]
That is good though, and it's convenient, cos who's got their laptop up and running and...
Texting, so you just need your phone, brilliant.
Mine couldn't do that, I don't know how to do that on my phone, I don't know how to get.
Eh? My brother wanted my post code, he said text it to me, I couldn't work out how to do W C and 1.
That's because you're an old man.
So I had to, had to write out double you see one.
Cos I didn't know how to do it, I just, I wouldn't do it for me.
Well, it's 83936 if you have that problem, right?
Right come on, get on with the quiz, I don't know, there's too many numbers.
Three, three, err, three clues, here we go, first one is err, "This Teletubby has got lice".
The initial there is P, so it's a band or an artist that starts with P, and the clue is "This Teletubby has got lice". Right?
I'm really already not holding out much hope for this...
Err, right, second one, I've just messed that first one up.
But when I give it out later it'll be, we'll, I'll sneak it in without - right, just don't repeat anything I say.
Play a record! Play a record, you're a fool. Play a record.
No, no, no, no, you've ruined it.
Press the button, press the button, it's off, ludicrous.
Red Vines, by Amy Mann, brilliant that isn't it?

On Xfm, 104.9. Well erm, Karl, mucked up Rockbusters, as usual, I mean I like it when me mucks it up early because it doesn't waste people's lives for 40 minutes, realising that he's mucked it up at the end.
So obviously, people are already, they know what it is, they know what it is already, they've said well it's Po-lice isn't it? You meant to say nits instead of lice.
You're an idiot, so that one's gone, so what have you got next?
Right so that's just an idea if you haven't heard it before that's, that's how me 'ead works. Right, "This Teletubby's got nits".
P, so Po is a Teletubby.
So when he says it's not only what the what the answer is, it's what the question was meant to be.
Alright, so there's only two so, you've got even a better chance, of winning and that.
So, second one is "I'm saving that money to buy condoms". Alright, think about it.
Yeah well that's too, everyone's got that one, I feel like saying it now.
Yeah, but don't say it now.
Yeah well you've got the have an easy one in there otherwise people'd get bored don't they.
First one was easy, you gave them the answer.
That's the easiest one we've ever had Po-lice.
And the, and the second one is err "When you're making bread, add a little bit of colour for a change". Alright? When you're making bread, add a little bit of colour, just change things a little bit.
So, what you've got there, I'm saving that money to buy condoms, initials JC.
An err, an when you're making some bread, just chuck some colour in there.
And d'yer know what I mean, change it a bit.
Yeah yeah, clue, the clue changes everytime.
The clue changes everytime, unlike the Times crossword, the clue changes everytime it's said.
93Xfm if you want to text in.
David Bowie, and Waterloo Sunset, love that loved the original.
Love that one love the original on Xfm 104.9.
Good work to David Bowie and The Kinks.
Yeah yeah yeah big time, big time.
Yeah erm well I don't normally read the paper.
But erm I was having a glance through the Daily Express, does anyone read the Daily Express.
Well you do at the moment look.
Read it out and then about 400 people'll know what's in it.
I was just reading, I was obviously attracted err by this little news item err "Gun raid by three Saddams" er "Three armed men..."
They're up to their old tricks again are they?

"Three armed men wearing Saddam Hussein masks were on the run last night after robbing a corner shop, the raiders threatened the worker with a handgun and knife, ordering them to open the till blah blah blah, get money out" and it say that "They also tried to rob an earlier shop, earlier in the day, Police said, 'We are linking to raids because descriptions of the offenders are very similar'."
What was the, what did the first one not quite get right.
"Well they looked very similar, I think it was Gaddafi, three Gaddafis."
"Right, cos that's weird, cos we've had three err Saddam Husseins, down the shop down the road."
"Oh well that's what I meant, Saddam Hussein."
"Well I assume so, I wouldn't have thought."
"I don't want to get the Gaddafi guys on the Saddam Hussein charge."

"No no no, I'm almost sure it, that it'd be the same one, I didn't know, ones got, got a moustache haven't they, and one like a, or they all got a moustache? I don't know, but I mean it's, there were three blokes with masks, middle eastern appear-, I don't know, but I mean I imagine it's the same, ones."
I erm, because I only ever seen erm robberies being planned in films.
So I don't know how it works, I assume there's.
I assume at some point someones got to get, the ringleaders got to get together and go "Well we need to wear masks obviously to disguise our faces."
"I was thinking of going with the regular stockings."
"No no no, no. I tell you what would be funny."
"Well I don't want to be funny."
"Wanna, we want to strike fear into the hearts of the people we're robbing."

"Kill two birds with one stone, we get the robbery and we have a laugh, fear, did you say you wanted to strike fear, well wear a mask of someone who's really scary. Who's the scariest bloke in the world?."
"I've got three of them, let's all wear Saddam Hussein mas-, it'll be a laugh."
"Well it's not, I don't want it to be a laugh, I'm robbing a bank."
"No but I won't do any, it won't hurt if we're robbing a bank and, that's what I want, I want to make money and have a laugh."
"Well why, that's not, I'm only in the money, I'm only in it for the money."
"And the laughs aren't important to me."
"We can also make a political point."
"I don't want to make a political point."
"I'm a thug, not I'm not clever."
"Well we can have a laugh, and we can make a political point, you know."
"Point you know, maybe we're stealing from the rich and-.
"Well nevermind Robin Hood, let's rob Barclay's, that's the..."
"Well I mean don't worry, I'm, I'm going to do my stuff."
"You're a, you're a comedian, you're not, I'm not sure you should be in this gang."
"Let's wear the masks, let's wear the masks."
